transcript.transcript: At George Mason University. This is July 11th, 1977, and we're going to. Oh, you want to do a three 50in the afternoon? Is that what you have? More or less. I had a calendar. Oh I see. Okay. And we're going to talk about his experience with Federal Theater. Let's begin, John, with how and when you joined the Federal Theater. Well, like many others, I joined the Federal Theater during the initial days of the WPA, when we were all looking for nonexistent jobs, and the Federal Theater was at that time an opportunity to do something interesting and still, of course, earn a living. And that's how I happened to join the Federal Theater, not because of an overpowering interest in the theater itself. What experience did you have? How did you first become interested in being a public relations man for the Federal Theater or whatever? Well, I suppose this is a a public relations man should be a person who's number one, an extrovert who likes to work with people, who has some degree of creativity and imagination and and foresight. And I suppose that all of those are characteristics that I had to some degree at the time. And whoever I talked with initially was the at the Federal Theatre Project that decided that that's what they would put me in. It's like when I first, uh, enlisted in the Army in 1942, they decided that I was what they called a rare bird, and they put me in public relations as also. So, you see, this is I just happened to be in that field. Seems as if from what you told me this morning, that your interest went back to even an earlier time. Well, yes, we're talking about the days when we did a lot of reading of Horatio Alger and and the Rover Boys. At that time, there was always a character involved with the with circus and traveling shows called the adjective man. And the adjective man was the man who went ahead of his show and told the people what this magnificent production was coming along and why he was the promotion man. And so that I was always interested in becoming an adjective man. So maybe that's what I was. Well, let's come back to that as far as what you did for Macbeth. But may I ask you to talk a little bit about your role with the Play Bureau? What did I know? That you also worked in the Play Bureau? Well, the Play Bureau was a branch or an agency of the Federal Theater that was involved in producing plays. And one of the major, major operations in production of plays has to be the reading of plays for approval. And I was assigned to reading plays. I think that I had a some sort of a literary background and knowledge that made that made me suitable for that, but I can't pinpoint it. Did you read all kinds of scripts? What? No. Primarily they assigned me to scripts that would be involved in the Negro theater. And while I wouldn't say that I was the token black, I guess I was the only black. Where did you have any instructions about what to read for in these scripts, or was that left kind of optional? Well, I think I was aware of the fact that they were reading for scripts that would be suitable for production and acceptable for production. That would tend to weed out anything that was unjust or unproducible or. Well. Militant. That is correct. Whatever. Okay. Um, could you give us a little background on the kind of people who did use the Lafayette unit as a focus during the 30s. How did they happen to be there? What had they done before the Lafayette unit was in operation? Well, the Federal Theater Project came along at the at the right in the midst of the Great Depression. And in New York City at that time, and particularly in Harlem, there were hundreds of unemployed people, many of them whose whose prior employment had been with the theater, either as performers or in some capacity. And so there was a natural inclination on their part to to gravitate to this federal theater. Additionally, as is the case in many other communities, and even now, there were many people who aspired to become a part of the theater, and so that this was an opportunity for them to break in. An opportunity they wouldn't have had otherwise. That is correct. Was that only now in the acting field, or did that. Oh, by no means. No. This the whole the whole gamut of theatrical production, ranging from A box office. Men to controllers. To stagehands. Lighting experts and directors, as well as the script writers. And presumably technical people as well. All, all the whole technical field was covered in the federal theatre, and every effort was made at that time to to put the Negroes as was the word acceptable use used then in charge of this activity. Would you say, is it fair to say that this federal theater provided an apprenticeship program, or were the skills already developed and just not used? In some cases the skills were developed, but they they needed sharpening and they needed to be brought up to professional standards where the doors had been closed before. Were you with the Lafayette unit for the from the very beginning? Did you see the early productions. I saw the early productions, but I was not a part of the project itself. But I did have many close friends who were a part of the early production of The Beginning. Uh, Carlton Moss, for example. And I think that Carlton was probably responsible for recommending me to handle this particular job of public relations. Let's go to that public relations job, that wonderful production of Macbeth. Can you talk about the first of all, the kind of impact that it had? Uh, we know that Houseman and Welles were the people who, uh, had charge, along with Rose McClendon of the Lafayette Unit in the early days. What what kind of atmosphere? Well, as befits its it's a it's a it's a direction and authorship of its production. And Orson Welles, this Macbeth was a unique one, probably, uh, in, in many, many instances. Number one, it was a Orson Welles version of Macbeth, and that was called the Negro version, with the locale changed to suit what he thought would be some of the talents of the the Negroes who were involved in it. Uh, additionally, uh, we felt that, uh, this Macbeth was a unique in that it was provided, for the first time in several decades, an opportunity for blacks to professionally perform Shakespearean plays before a paying audience. And I say for the first time in several decades, because it was not the first time there was in New York City back in 1827, a Grove Theater. Grove theater, where they used to perform Shakespearean plays. But the hooligans, the hoodlum element, chased them off the streets of New York at that time. So now they were they found a welcome home. And so there was a unit. There was a place to perform professionally and also now presumably the kind of guidance, the kind of direction, the kind of, uh, atmosphere that would allow people to. Well, I say that ranging from IRA Aldridge, who was one of the great Shakespearean actors of his time, uh, to Paul Robeson and others who followed him. Uh, blacks have always been interested in Shakespeare, but this is the first time it's ever been done in such a unique fashion. Mhm. What about some of the people who performed in Macbeth? Uh, I know you have in front of you a program from that time. Yes. I was just looking at this program and of course it invokes a number of memories. I see our Air Canada Lee, who played the Banquo, of course, as a deceased. It has been for several years. But Canada was a former professional boxer, as well as a violinist who who came into the Federal Theater and went on to rise to very great heights after that, and became one of the leading actors of his time. In fact, not only on the on the boards, but before the motion picture cameras of Hollywood cameras. Canada, of course, has since died. And then, of course, we have people like, uh, Tommy Anderson, who was who was played a role as in the play and as well as who was a director, uh, did his job so well that they invited him to go from to Hollywood to direct a production out there, uh, in Hollywood. I see a name here that Beryl Banfield who took the part of a second page boy who is now a school principal in Harlem, and I see the name of, uh, of a one of our stage managers, assistant stage manager Edward Dudley Jr. And Edward Dudley Jr. Junior happens to be now one of the most distinguished judges in the city of New York, a judge of the Supreme Court. Of course, the scenery on this was done by Perry Watkins, who was a great designer in his day. And before this, before the Federal Theater couldn't get a job because he was a black man. But the Federal Theater opened the doors for him. And now Perry Watkins is very much sought after to do stage design and sets so that there are a number of people in this 110 person cast who who used this as a stepping stone and are now famous in their own right. Let's take the music. Leonard De Pauw, who did the music for directed the chorus, is now the a musical high ranking official at the Lincoln Center Performing Arts Center in New York City. I believe he's the director of music there. You took all of this 100 people on tour in the Midwest, and I wonder if you would share some of your experiences with us in trying to get that number of people accommodations under any circumstances? Well, you know, in order to, in order to, to, to to address ourselves to the to the uniqueness of that situation, you would have to take into account the fact that this was 110 black people and travel for black people at that time, as it was up until a decade ago, was not the most pleasant or easiest thing in the world. We were living in a strictly Jim Crow situation where the hotel accommodations for blacks were non-existent. In many cases, where theater accommodations for blacks were non-existent in many cases, and so that it was necessary in order to find a living accommodations for these people. For me to go ahead of the show two weeks and to arrange for lodging and for community relations and for public relations and so forth. And that was the fascinating part about this, is that we we were able to do this successfully, even taking them down to the centennial celebration in Dallas, Texas, where, of course, we became one of the hits of the show and where they had never seen blacks perform before. But we did it and did it well. And I don't think we had any, uh, any racial incidents at all. And I found the entire tour or just, well. We had no overt racial incidents on the entire tour. But of course, there was a lot of unpleasantness in many towns because you couldn't in some towns, you couldn't even get a Coca-Cola in the downtown store drugstores. And these are people from New York who were not accustomed to Jim Crow. Uh, take a town like Indianapolis, which was not the most liberal town in the world, but we played there and blacks couldn't even go into the theater before we went there, but we opened up the theater and so that we in many cases, played a dual role. We were door openers in more than one respect. How did you go about the job of finding accommodations? If there were no hotels, then what did you do with this 100 people? Well, uh, in the first place, at that time, in a strictly segregated economy and a strictly segregated community, uh, you always pick out the community leaders who would give you who would steer you to to this type of type of accommodations. You would go to the YMCA, which was at that time totally segregated. You could go to the churches, which are still segregated, and you could go to the schools, which at that time segregated. And from that leadership, if you're able to develop a relationship with those people, they could put you on to just where to go. That would be primarily private homes, then. Private homes and 1 or 2 instances of boarding houses. But no, except for Cleveland. There was a hotel at 55th in and Central Avenue called the, uh, I think it was the. Oh, I've forgotten the name of the hotel, but it was a very large hotel. It was owned by blacks or run by blacks, but it's now a rundown place. But at that time, it was the best we had. And at that time, it was what was called maybe a fourth rate fleabag. So it was, uh, rooming with private families. What about meals, then? Well, sometimes they took the meals in and sometimes they took them out. But bear in mind that none of us made much money. And at $23, $23.86 a week, uh, there wasn't a whole lot of money to eat with on the road, even though your transportation was taken care of. But they managed. Is there one place on the tour that stands out in your mind as you think back more than another? I know you've spoken about Dallas. Well, Dallas, Texas, of course, because it was the first time I'd ever been to Texas. And of course, I had no real fears about going there, except that we had some unpleasant experiences on the ride in the Jim Crow car. Although I had my transportation call for first class accommodations all the way. I was forced to get out of the Pullman at a place called millet, Arkansas, where I had to get out in the middle of the night and get back in the Jim Crow car and ride. But that's those are the things we we were. If you live in a Jim Crow society, you get accustomed to that sort of thing. Not that you ever really going to get accustomed to accept it, but you just got accustomed to living with it. And again, these were all New Yorkers who had not most of them had not had this experience before. Well, they had it perhaps most. Most people who live in New York had come there by way of someplace else. But I came to New York by way of new Jersey, which was there was a decided absence of overt segregation, but we still knew that there was in many cases, a difference was made. The tour then you just said that you opened many doors for black performers in the Federal Theater in this tour. Um, then presumably that that was one of the successes of the Federal Theater. The fact that they could somehow bring the white and black communities together, that there could be this kind of success in the country. There's no question about that. The Federal Theater, not only in New York but elsewhere, gave gave Negroes their first opportunity to to develop in every aspect of the theater, from the performing, from the playwriting to technical aspects, as well as to see a theatrical, a live theatrical production. Thousands of black people saw federal theater productions, as well as thousands of whites who had never seen one before. Let's talk a little bit about the audience for Macbeth. You said that obviously you were a success. But again, do you remember any particular audiences on this tour that any kind of appreciation or any kind of outstanding incident about this tour? Well, as in the case of any, any production, there was always a sort of an excitement about the first night or opening night in any town. And this is a unique situation where an all black group was playing, let's say, in Detroit or in Cleveland or in Indianapolis or in New York for that matter. Our opening night was very big, with klieg lights, band police and crowds milling around. So there was always that excitement that comes from an opening night. And I'm very grateful for the experience of having lived through that, something that I have only read about before, since I'm not a performer, but to have been a part of that opening night performance and to see perhaps the results of some of the work that you did in laying the groundwork with the newspapers and the newsroom beforehand to see it come to pass as as a big event in those towns. How long did you stay in a single place, or did it depend upon? Well, it depend on the circumstances varied. I would I would stay until, oh, maybe a stay a couple of days at least, and then go on to the next place. Go on and get it ready there, I guess. Yeah. Uh, what about newspaper contacts? Uh, what was it like to go into a place like Indianapolis and say, here, this cast is coming? Uh, why don't you give us some publicity on that angle of it? Well, very interesting one, too. Well, there again, it called for, uh, diplomacy and, uh, thick skin and ability to break down doors, which, uh, I possess. It's as simple as that. But it was no easy, um, uh, public relations job to go to the newspaper. Get them. To cover. It was not. But we managed somehow. What kind of excuses did they give you for not wanting to promote something? Well, they. Oddly enough, I never ran into that. But it's just always a little, uh, I would say excitement, but. Well, there's a Negro in here who's a press agent for this show. And in many cases, I guess they thought because my name was Silvera, that I was some kind of Spaniard or something like that, I don't know, and nobody ever said that. But I always gathered that there were, you know, he said, we'll talk with him anyway. Right, right. He's not one of them. There might not be one of them. Well, uh, what did you. Well, the tour was a great success. And then you found your way back in to New York again. What was your next assignment for the Federal Theater? Well, after that, after the Macbeth, I went with the National Service Bureau, which is in a part of the Federal Theater project, trying to develop plays in them and I. Whatever if my interest in writing plays became sharpened and I was joined with Abe Hill, who was a well-known playwright, in trying to write a living newspaper, which is a form of theatre that in which the federal theatre was very much interested. And we developed one called Liberty Deferred. I think you have a copy of the script in your library here. It was never it was never produced. But if you read it, you might want to produce it. I would like to. Particularly after roots, because I'm wondering if Alex Haley didn't have a chance to see that. Yeah. I think that, um. Could you elaborate a little bit about why the Federal Theatre found that living in newspaper form so attractive? Because they certainly were encouraging people to write living newspapers. But what was it about that form that made it a vehicle? Well, it was a forerunner of television news. That's what it was. It was a forerunner because there you had an opportunity to see, uh, the events, the current events or events of the time that they were depicting live. Live before you like you see them on television today. And that's why The Living Newspaper really was a forerunner of that. For purposes of the tape. Because I'd like to get it on record. I know that you're the, uh, the Utopia is your brainchild. Would you be willing to describe briefly for the tape what Lynch utopia is about, and how you happened to get that particular brainstorm? Because I've seen you have a number of them in the few days here. But how did Lynch Utopia come to be born? And what is it just so that people. Well, nothing is more effective than ridicule and humor, and I think that the people will get tired of the serious preaching about some of the things that are wrong civil wrongs. And if you can laugh them out of existence, maybe you'd be a more effective job. And so we decided that there was this place called Utopia, where lynch victims would go and use them. And and the symbol, I believe, of Lynch. Utopia was a rope around your neck. And this is the way it happened. That's all. So that when someone was lynched, presumably they would go to. The place that's right, called Lynch. And then they would tell the details about. How they how they got. There. That's very clever idea. I'm going to do ask you to do one more thing for me. I'm going to put the, uh, charts in front of you. And this is these are the charts for the Lafayette unit. Are there any other place that you were particularly interested in or thought were particularly effective? Well, you have here some that became famous and see some famous names here, too. Frank Wilson was the one who did Brother Mose and and Walk together. Children was a great actor and for his time he did a great job. They they gave their first performance in 1936 and ran for four months. And then, of course, Gus Smith, who did them, was co-authored this play called turpentine. Turpentine was a story about labor conditions and turpentine camp. And at the time of the dyes hearings and the congressional hearings, turpentine was cited as an example of how the labor conditions and working conditions could be distorted. But they weren't really distorted. They were. They were just showing how they could be brought down front. Uh, then we have here, of course, Haiti, which was a very, very, excellently done story of Toussaint Louverture. And in Haiti and, uh, you had all the color and all the suspense and all the romance that, uh, needed to to enjoy an evening in the theater about Haiti. Those are just some of the few that you have listed here. I see you have even Eubie Blake, who is currently, uh, a still recognized as a great musician and pianist. See here, he was an author of a production called Swingin, and that was back in 1937 to 1938. Musical vaudeville was called. Just hearing you talk about the plays. One gets the sense, and I think it's a correct sense, that there was a tremendous variety in the kind of plays that were put on at the Lafayette. No question about it. Ranging from children's theater, uh, Androcles and the lion, which was not exactly children's theater but was of interest to the general audience, uh, the whole gamut. We had you name it, and we did it. Uh, from the perspective of 1977, looking back on what was done, say, maybe going back specifically to turpentine, or specifically to liberty, to fur. John. How do those plays look to you today as you review Liberty Deferred with an eye to production? Or as you think about perhaps someone putting on turpentine? Were they militant plays where you considered, uh, militants if you talked about labor conditions in a turpentine camp? Well, yes. At that time it was, uh, if you spoke out against what you saw as an injustice, you could very easily be tagged or labeled as a communist. Uh, not so easy to do that today, even though, in fact, it's illegal. But this was a common excuse for, uh, for for ordinary militancy just to say, well, these are communists or leftists. And we had a very active that was at the inception of the labor union. We had a very active group called the Workers Alliance that was trying to better working conditions among blacks, and they were also active in the federal theater. is always that danger of of being accused and in many cases there were. There were some communists connected with it. How would Liberty Deferred look to a modern day audience? What would they think about it as a 30? I don't know. I don't know. I rather think that I would be considered a if it had been produced in those days, I would have been considered a radical. And I don't think I'm considered that now. In fact, I'm considered a conservative. Where did you think of yourself as a radical during the 30s? Well, yes, I guess I did, because one of my ambitions at that time was to lead Silvera's raiders into South Africa. Tell me about that. Well how's that? I'd like to hear about that. No, that was just one of my ambitions. I used to dream about it. And. But of course, being able to articulate that dream kept me from going to South Africa, I think because while I was Commissioner of Human Rights of the State of New York, I was asked by the General Counsel General of South Africa to visit South Africa. And they had I think they had the trip all arranged. And I remember distinctly when, after we closed our conversation on that happy note, I said, well, this is going to be a lifelong ambition, you know. And I used to when I was a young lieutenant, I used to dream of leading Silveira's race in South Africa. I never heard from him again. So I talked my way out of a trip to South Africa by telling my. My dreams. Were a little ahead of your time even then, weren't. You? That's right. That's right. Well, I thank you for this time. And I'm going to I promise you, I'm going to keep trying to get you on tape as soon as I get another format together. Thank you. Okay. Well, it's always a pleasure to talk about the Federal Theatre, because I think the more we talk about it, the more people will realize that this was a great moment in American cultural history.

lines.line: > The speaker begins by setting the scene at George Mason University on July 11th, 1977, discussing the purpose of the meeting which is to talk about his experiences with the Federal Theater. He joined the Federal Theater during the early days of the WPA when jobs were scarce, seeing it as an opportunity to work in an interesting field while earning a living.

metadata.title: Introduction to Federal Theater Experience
metadata.synopsis: The speaker begins by setting the scene at George Mason University on July 11th, 1977, discussing the purpose of the meeting which is to talk about his experiences with the Federal Theater. He joined the Federal Theater during the early days of the WPA when jobs were scarce, seeing it as an opportunity to work in an interesting field while earning a living.

lines.line: > The speaker describes his role within the Federal Theater's Play Bureau, which was responsible for producing plays. He was involved in reading and approving plays, particularly focusing on scripts for the Negro theater. Despite not being the only black person, he played a significant role in selecting suitable and producible scripts.

metadata.title: Roles in the Federal Theater
metadata.synopsis: The speaker describes his role within the Federal Theater's Play Bureau, which was responsible for producing plays. He was involved in reading and approving plays, particularly focusing on scripts for the Negro theater. Despite not being the only black person, he played a significant role in selecting suitable and producible scripts.

lines.line: # The Lafayette Unit's Formation and Impact

> The speaker discusses the formation of the Lafayette Unit during the Great Depression, highlighting its role in providing employment and opportunities for black individuals in Harlem who were previously involved in theater or aspired to be. This unit not only provided jobs but also allowed for the development of professional skills in various theatrical roles.

metadata.title: The Lafayette Unit's Formation and Impact
metadata.synopsis: The speaker discusses the formation of the Lafayette Unit during the Great Depression, highlighting its role in providing employment and opportunities for black individuals in Harlem who were previously involved in theater or aspired to be. This unit not only provided jobs but also allowed for the development of professional skills in various theatrical roles.

lines.line: # Experiences with Macbeth Production and Tour

> The speaker shares his experiences working in public relations for the production of Macbeth, which was directed by Orson Welles and featured a predominantly black cast. He discusses the unique aspects of this production and the challenges faced during the tour, including racial segregation and the logistics of performing in different cities.

metadata.title: Experiences with Macbeth Production and Tour
metadata.synopsis: The speaker shares his experiences working in public relations for the production of Macbeth, which was directed by Orson Welles and featured a predominantly black cast. He discusses the unique aspects of this production and the challenges faced during the tour, including racial segregation and the logistics of performing in different cities.

lines.line: > The speaker details the difficulties in arranging accommodations for a large group during the tour, especially due to racial segregation. He had to plan extensively, often arranging stays in private homes or segregated facilities, and faced various challenges due to the racial climate of the time.

metadata.title: Challenges in Tour Accommodations
metadata.synopsis: The speaker details the difficulties in arranging accommodations for a large group during the tour, especially due to racial segregation. He had to plan extensively, often arranging stays in private homes or segregated facilities, and faced various challenges due to the racial climate of the time.

lines.line: > Following the Macbeth tour, the speaker moved on to work with the National Service Bureau of the Federal Theater, where he focused on developing plays and a living newspaper. He reflects on the potential impact of these projects and his role in them, highlighting the innovative nature of the living newspaper as a precursor to modern news media.

metadata.title: Post-Macbeth Career and Projects
metadata.synopsis: Following the Macbeth tour, the speaker moved on to work with the National Service Bureau of the Federal Theater, where he focused on developing plays and a living newspaper. He reflects on the potential impact of these projects and his role in them, highlighting the innovative nature of the living newspaper as a precursor to modern news media.

lines.line: # Reflecting on the Federal Theater's Legacy

> The speaker reflects on the significance of the Federal Theater in American cultural history, emphasizing its role in providing opportunities and opening doors for black individuals in theater. He believes that discussing the Federal Theater helps in recognizing its importance and the impact it had on the cultural landscape.

metadata.title: Reflecting on the Federal Theater's Legacy
metadata.synopsis: The speaker reflects on the significance of the Federal Theater in American cultural history, emphasizing its role in providing opportunities and opening doors for black individuals in theater. He believes that discussing the Federal Theater helps in recognizing its importance and the impact it had on the cultural landscape.

story.title: John Silvera, July 11, 1977
story.description:
Interviewee: Silvera, John

Interviewer: Brown, Lorraine

Occupation: Publicist

Unit: FTP, New York, N.Y.

Date: 1977-07-11

Length: 30 mins
